newsitem.title: USA: Miami Beach, Fla., plans five bond issues.
newsitem.headline: Miami Beach, Fla., plans five bond issues.

text.p: Miami Beach plans five bond issues totalling up to $88 million in the next six months or so, city Finance Director Robert Nachlinger said Monday.
Pricing is expected in early December on a $15 million general obligation bond issue, with Smith Barney Inc as senior manager.
Filling out the syndicate are Goldman Sachs & Co, William R. Hough & Co and PaineWebber Inc, which make up one of the city's two standing underwriter teams.

A $15 million parking revenue bond issue is expected to price in early January. Underwriters include Bear Stearns & Co Inc, Morgan Stanley & Co Inc, AIBC Investment Services Corp, and Raymond James & Assiociates Inc. They comprise the city's second standing team, but it was unclear which would be senior manager on the deal.
Pricing is expected in early February on an $18 million stormwater improvment revenue bond issue, with William R. Hough as senior manager.

A tax increment revenue bond of $20 million to $25 million is scheduled for pricing in March with AIBC as senior manager. It will finance redevelopment of the city's South Pointe neighborhood at the southern tip of Miami Beach.

The last issue, a $15 million tax revenue bond of the City Center Redevelopment Area, is still tentative. Pricing is expected in the spring, with Morgan Stanely as senior manager. The issue will help finance a 400-room hotel south of the city's convention center.
Additionally, city commissioners have given conceptual approval for two $40 million loan projects, both of which will be financed through state municipal pools, Nachlinger said.

One would offer 20-year loans to high-rise apartment and condominium owners to finance installation of sprinklers. The sprinklers were mandated under a 1991 fire code change, but the city has delayed enforcement. Some 71 buildings over 70 feet tall still lack sprinklers and would be eligible for the loans.

The second project is a $40 million revolving pool to finance work to bury electric lines, gas lines, and fiber-optic cable for television, telephone and internet transmission. Burying the lines underground would reduce damage in the event of another major hurricane, a lesson learned when Hurricane Andrew destroyed the entire above-ground electric grid in some communities south of Miami in 1992, Nachlinger said.
"Quite frankly it's probably a $200 million program just for Miami Beach," Nachlinger said.
Both of the loans would be covenent debt repaid through annual appropriations, he said.
